     265             : #endif/* JS_USE_CUSTOM_ALLOCATOR */
     266             : 
     267             : #include <new>
     268             : 
     269             : /*
     270             :  * Low-level memory management in SpiderMonkey:
     271             :  *
     272             :  *  ** Do not use the standard malloc/free/realloc: SpiderMonkey allows these
     273             :  *     to be redefined (via JS_USE_CUSTOM_ALLOCATOR) and Gecko even #define's
     274             :  *     these symbols.
     275             :  *
     276             :  *  ** Do not use the builtin C++ operator new and delete: these throw on
     277             :  *     error and we cannot override them not to.
     278             :  *
     279             :  * Allocation:
     280             :  *
     281             :  * - If the lifetime of the allocation is tied to the lifetime of a GC-thing
     282             :  *   (that is, finalizing the GC-thing will free the allocation), call one of
     283             :  *   the following functions:
     284             :  *
     285             :  *     JSContext::{malloc_,realloc_,calloc_,new_}
     286             :  *     JSRuntime::{malloc_,realloc_,calloc_,new_}
     287             :  *
     288             :  *   These functions accumulate the number of bytes allocated which is used as
     289             :  *   part of the GC-triggering heuristic.
     290             :  *
     291             :  *   The difference between the JSContext and JSRuntime versions is that the
     292             :  *   cx version reports an out-of-memory error on OOM. (This follows from the
     293             :  *   general SpiderMonkey idiom that a JSContext-taking function reports its
     294             :  *   own errors.)
     295             :  *
     296             :  * - Otherwise, use js_malloc/js_realloc/js_calloc/js_new
     297             :  *
     298             :  * Deallocation:
     299             :  *
     300             :  * - Ordinarily, use js_free/js_delete.
     301             :  *
     302             :  * - For deallocations during GC finalization, use one of the following
     303             :  *   operations on the FreeOp provided to the finalizer:
     304             :  *
     305             :  *     FreeOp::{free_,delete_}
     306             :  *
     307             :  *   The advantage of these operations is that the memory is batched and freed
     308             :  *   on another thread.
     309             :  */
     310             : 
     311             : /*
     312             :  * Given a class which should provide a 'new' method, add
     313             :  * JS_DECLARE_NEW_METHODS (see js::MallocProvider for an example).
     314             :  *
     315             :  * Note: Do not add a ; at the end of a use of JS_DECLARE_NEW_METHODS,
     316             :  * or the build will break.
     317             :  */
     318             : #define JS_DECLARE_NEW_METHODS(NEWNAME, ALLOCATOR, QUALIFIERS) \
     319             :     template <class T, typename... Args> \
     320             :     QUALIFIERS T * \
     321             :     NEWNAME(Args&&... args) MOZ_HEAP_ALLOCATOR { \
     322             :         void* memory = ALLOCATOR(sizeof(T)); \
     323             :         return MOZ_LIKELY(memory) \
     324             :             ? new(memory) T(mozilla::Forward<Args>(args)...) \
     325             :             : nullptr; \
     326             :     }
     327             : 
     328             : /*
     329             :  * Given a class which should provide 'make' methods, add
     330             :  * JS_DECLARE_MAKE_METHODS (see js::MallocProvider for an example).  This
     331             :  * method is functionally the same as JS_DECLARE_NEW_METHODS: it just declares
     332             :  * methods that return mozilla::UniquePtr instances that will singly-manage
     333             :  * ownership of the created object.
     334             :  *
     335             :  * Note: Do not add a ; at the end of a use of JS_DECLARE_MAKE_METHODS,
     336             :  * or the build will break.
     337             :  */
     338             : #define JS_DECLARE_MAKE_METHODS(MAKENAME, NEWNAME, QUALIFIERS)\
     339             :     template <class T, typename... Args> \
     340             :     QUALIFIERS mozilla::UniquePtr<T, JS::DeletePolicy<T>> \
     341             :     MAKENAME(Args&&... args) MOZ_HEAP_ALLOCATOR { \
     342             :         T* ptr = NEWNAME<T>(mozilla::Forward<Args>(args)...); \
     343             :         return mozilla::UniquePtr<T, JS::DeletePolicy<T>>(ptr); \
     344             :     }
     345             : 
     346       17541 : JS_DECLARE_NEW_METHODS(js_new, js_malloc, static MOZ_ALWAYS_INLINE)
     347             :

     501             : namespace js {
     502             : 
     503             : /* Integral types for all hash functions. */
     504             : typedef uint32_t HashNumber;
     505             : const unsigned HashNumberSizeBits = 32;
     506             : 
     507             : namespace detail {
     508             : 
     509             : /*
     510             :  * Given a raw hash code, h, return a number that can be used to select a hash
     511             :  * bucket.
     512             :  *
     513             :  * This function aims to produce as uniform an output distribution as possible,
     514             :  * especially in the most significant (leftmost) bits, even though the input
     515             :  * distribution may be highly nonrandom, given the constraints that this must
     516             :  * be deterministic and quick to compute.
     517             :  *
     518             :  * Since the leftmost bits of the result are best, the hash bucket index is
     519             :  * computed by doing ScrambleHashCode(h) / (2^32/N) or the equivalent
     520             :  * right-shift, not ScrambleHashCode(h) % N or the equivalent bit-mask.
     521             :  *
     522             :  * FIXME: OrderedHashTable uses a bit-mask; see bug 775896.
     523             :  */
     524             : inline HashNumber
     525             : ScrambleHashCode(HashNumber h)
     526             : {
     527             :     /*
     528             :      * Simply returning h would not cause any hash tables to produce wrong
     529             :      * answers. But it can produce pathologically bad performance: The caller
     530             :      * right-shifts the result, keeping only the highest bits. The high bits of
     531             :      * hash codes are very often completely entropy-free. (So are the lowest
     532             :      * bits.)
     533             :      *
     534             :      * So we use Fibonacci hashing, as described in Knuth, The Art of Computer
     535             :      * Programming, 6.4. This mixes all the bits of the input hash code h.
     536             :      *
     537             :      * The value of goldenRatio is taken from the hex
     538             :      * expansion of the golden ratio, which starts 1.9E3779B9....
     539             :      * This value is especially good if values with consecutive hash codes
     540             :      * are stored in a hash table; see Knuth for details.
     541             :      */
     542             :     static const HashNumber goldenRatio = 0x9E3779B9U;
     543     7362840 :     return h * goldenRatio;
     544             : }
     545             : 
     546             : } /* namespace detail */
     547             : 
     548             : } /* namespace js */
     549             : 
     550             : /* sixgill annotation defines */
     551             : #ifndef HAVE_STATIC_ANNOTATIONS
     552             : # define HAVE_STATIC_ANNOTATIONS
     553             : # ifdef XGILL_PLUGIN
     554             : #  define STATIC_PRECONDITION(COND)         __attribute__((precondition(#COND)))
     555             : #  define STATIC_PRECONDITION_ASSUME(COND)  __attribute__((precondition_assume(#COND)))
     556             : #  define STATIC_POSTCONDITION(COND)        __attribute__((postcondition(#COND)))
     557             : #  define STATIC_POSTCONDITION_ASSUME(COND) __attribute__((postcondition_assume(#COND)))
     558             : #  define STATIC_INVARIANT(COND)            __attribute__((invariant(#COND)))
     559             : #  define STATIC_INVARIANT_ASSUME(COND)     __attribute__((invariant_assume(#COND)))
     560             : #  define STATIC_ASSUME(COND)                        \
     561             :   JS_BEGIN_MACRO                                     \
     562             :     __attribute__((assume_static(#COND), unused))    \
     563             :     int STATIC_PASTE1(assume_static_, __COUNTER__);  \
     564             :   JS_END_MACRO
     565             : # else /* XGILL_PLUGIN */
     566             : #  define STATIC_PRECONDITION(COND)          /* nothing */
     567             : #  define STATIC_PRECONDITION_ASSUME(COND)   /* nothing */
     568             : #  define STATIC_POSTCONDITION(COND)         /* nothing */
     569             : #  define STATIC_POSTCONDITION_ASSUME(COND)  /* nothing */
     570             : #  define STATIC_INVARIANT(COND)             /* nothing */
     571             : #  define STATIC_INVARIANT_ASSUME(COND)      /* nothing */
     572             : #  define STATIC_ASSUME(COND)          JS_BEGIN_MACRO /* nothing */ JS_END_MACRO
     573             : # endif /* XGILL_PLUGIN */
     574             : # define STATIC_SKIP_INFERENCE STATIC_INVARIANT(skip_inference())
     575             : #endif /* HAVE_STATIC_ANNOTATIONS */
     576             : 
     577             : #endif /* js_Utility_h */
